key_points: Aug 30, 2021: The last U.S. troops left Afghanistan, ending America's longest war.
Sept. 11, 2001: U.S. involvement began after attacks in the U.S. by al Qaeda from Afghanistan.
Oct. 7, 2001: U.S. forces started airstrikes against Taliban and al Qaeda, with no significant initial combat deployment.
Dec 2001: Osama bin Laden escaped U.S. bombing in Tora Bora, Afghanistan, to Pakistan.
May 2, 2003: Major combat operations declared over; focus shifts towards Iraq, enabling Taliban resurgence.
Feb. 17, 2009: President Obama increased U.S. troops, exceeding 100,000 in 2010 for counter-insurgency operations.
May 1, 2011: U.S. forces killed Osama bin Laden in Pakistan.
May 27, 2014: Obama initiated a drawdown, focusing on training Afghan military, planning full withdrawal by end of 2016.
Feb. 29, 2020: Trump administration signs agreement with Taliban for U.S. troop withdrawal, Taliban to negotiate peace.
Aug. 26, 2021: ISIS suicide bomb at Kabul airport killed scores, including 13 U.S. troops.
spokespersons: U.S. General Frank McKenzie (Head of U.S. Central Command)
